metadata.subject: Intellectual Jazz - The WWW Conference Schedule and Participant Biographies

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: Mike Block works as musical director and second cellist alongside Yo-Yo Ma
Co-founded Applied Proteomics and co-direct the USC-NCI Physical Sciences in Oncology Center
Conference host and organizer pairing participants for conversations

analysis.purpose: To organize an intellectual conference featuring improvised conversations between leading thinkers across multiple disciplines
analysis.significance: Brings together an extraordinary collection of world-renowned scientists, artists, musicians, architects, and thinkers for unique conversational pairings

notable_quotes: Improvised conversation in this manner is a new form but a wonderful conversation is perhaps the oldest human media for creative discourse. So in that sense, this is a great leap backwards.
The goal is to find some threads that have not emerged before as you speak with your partner, which will encapsulate a type of honesty and a non-predicted path in response to each other.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found. Document describes a legitimate intellectual conference with voluntary participation.

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed or evidenced. Document contains conference materials and participant biographies.

details: References to media coverage of participants' accomplishments
Mention of journalists Mary Jordan and David Brooks as participants
Discussion of conference filming and app development for content distribution

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be a legitimate intellectual conference featuring many publicly known figures. The document contains biographical information that is largely already public knowledge about these prominent individuals.

analysis.summary: This document contains the schedule, participant biographies, and organizational details for the WWW Conference (World, Water, Wealth, etc.) organized by Richard Saul Wurman in September 2012, featuring improvised conversations between 50+ leading thinkers across science, arts, technology, and humanities, with detailed planning memos about the conference format and digital preservation strategy.
